result.execSummary:
The defendant Leandrew Rojann Riley was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Leandrew Rojann Riley

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Court will consider motion for expungement upon successful completion of probation.
15A 019650/reversed to correct: to make sure bond applied correctly.

Defendant Leandrew Rojann Riley in court with attorney Michael Jude.  Sarah McNutt appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy court clerk cmt.
Pursuant to plea negotiations and on State's motion, Court orders both penalty enhancers, Use of a Dangerous Weapon and Domestic Abuse, DISMISSED.

As to Count 1 as amended:   
Defendant changes his plea to GUILTY.  Defendant examined as to his plea, advised of his Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty.   Court found that defendant knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently waived his rights.  Guilty Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights and Addendum received and filed.  Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea.  Court found defendant guilty and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record.

Sentencing proceeded.  Statements by parties.  
Court ordered defendant to serve 30 days in the House of Correction, with 7 days credit for time served.  COURT IMPOSED BUT STAYED the sentence and placed defendant on Probation with the State of Wisconsin, Department of Corrections for a period of 12 months with the following conditions:
 - Mental health assessment. 
 - Anger management course. 
 - No further violations of the law. 
 - Obtain/maintain employment.
 - No further violations of the law. 
 - No contact with victim.
 - Pay costs, fees and surcharges during term of probation or civil judgment.
Court will consider motion for expungement upon successful completion of probation.
